comments.text:
There is a lot of incompatibility between STL files produced by different CAD packages. I often want to make minor adjustments to published designs, and more often than not have problems importing them into FreeCAD.
Having done some experiments following your comment, it seems slicers are similarly fussy. Slic3r does an automatic repair on the STL file for this "thing", and then seems to slice it correctly. It also allows you to save the "repaired" STL file.
I'd suggest you try repairing the STL file in this way, and then using your favourite slicer to get your print.

title: Prusa i3 MK2: V2 holder clips for Y-axis' bearings (LM8UU and igus drylin RJ4JP-01-08)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
ATTENTION: Please read the project's update notes at the bottom of this page!

I add to my effort to make the linear system of the Prusa i3 MK2 more stable, reliable and more comfortable to adjust these clips for the ordinary LM8UU ball bearings, which come with the machine. As with Thing 1837936 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1837936) you don't need the weak zip ties any longer. Instead, you can mount your bearings "pre-aligned" to the Y-carriage by using two M3 screws per bearing.

A further advantage is that the bearings are now aligned in the center of the Y-carriages notch. So there is no longer the risk of misaligning the bearings vertically. Nevertheless, the Y-carriage has still the full range of operation, because the clips for the side of the carriage with the two bearings are designed to slide into the gab of the frames corner pieces.

There are still two things to consider:

  1. Though I had the LM8UU bearings and tested the fit of the clips on them, I have not tested them mounted directly on my machine. The reason is that both of my machines are equipped with the igus RJZM-01-8 bushings and in heavy use.
    So I ask the Thingiverse community to give me feedback on how the clips perform and what I should improve.

  2. According to nillabean (YouTube Video: VYW1p3T9tKo), the drylin igus RJ4JP-01-08 are very good, stiff and yet affordable linear bearings (not to confuse with the omnipresent RJMP versions). I have tested it myself and also got positive feedback from the community. They fit, and therefore the RJ4JP-01-08 are now "officially supported" by these clips! :-D

If you like to buy the igus DryLin RJ4JP-01-08 bearings, then please consider buying it via my affiliate links provided next. No costs for you but you help me pay my bills.

  • http://amzn.to/2BkMx1h (Amazon Germany)
  • http://amzn.to/2BijLOK (Amazon UK)

Thank you!

Please also take a look at my other designs, printer parts, and tools.

If you like to support me and my work, please consider to follow me

  • here at Thingiverse
  • Twitter
  • Instagram
  • YouTube

Sending a tip over Thingiverse will buy me some coffee to stay productive. :-)
Thank you very much.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

Not important

Notes:

Use as many perimeters (shells) as needed to fill up the gaps. I used six on my 0.4 mm nozzle.
I wouldn't recommend a brim because it makes the cleanup more difficult.

You need

2x DoubleBushingSideClip
1x SingleBushingSideClip

Orient the DoubleBushingSideClips correctly, so that the carriage can move along the entire length of the shafts.

Clean your print from any unintended filament remains, like a brim. It is crucial that the bearings do not get misaligned by any derbies.

The bolts that showed to have a perfect fit are M3x16 - I use stainless steel 2.5 mm hexagon socket screws with a cylindric head like also found inside the Prusa i3 MK2 kit.

No. 3

Besides the positive feedback that the clips also work with the igus drylin RJ4JP-01-08, I have also tested it myself now. They fit!

Many thanks to igus for sending me the test samples! :-)

So this is no "work in progress" anymore.

No. 2:

Version 2 (V2) of the clips is now online.

You'll find the clips as single objects or as a complete set to download and print.

Changelog:

  1. The clips now hold the LM8UU bearings more tightly
  2. The bearings are pressed against the Y frame to stop them from spinning.
  3. The M3 screw holes are narrower now to provide better grip for their thread.
No. 1:

So, I made the changes suggested by bret4 and tried different approaches of how to reverse the screw direction.

The good...

1) I lowered the clearance of both, the bearing hole and the screw holes. Right, this was a good point. Both are now much tighter in fit, and should not wiggle or get loose anymore.

2) I lowered the surface that faces the Y-carriage frame by 0.2 mm (one layer's height), which again tightens the bearing much more by pressing it against the carriage frame.

The bad...

As shown on the following pictures reversing the screw direction results in a big problem: The screw-heads are crashing against the X-Y-metal-frame. My frame is already lower than Prusa Research suggests in its assembly manual, because my frame also rests on the table where the printer stands. Every other user that has assembled the frame as suggested by Prusa will obviously have the same trouble.

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/4928832/lm8uuClipsProblems/ZylindricButtonHeadComparison.jpg

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/4928832/lm8uuClipsProblems/ButtonHeadScrew.jpg

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/4928832/lm8uuClipsProblems/ZylindricScrew.jpg

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/4928832/lm8uuClipsProblems/CrashAgainstTheFrame.jpg

The ugly...

Trying to move the screws more towards the Y-carriage frame to hide the heads inside the clips and preventing them from crashing against the X-Y-frame results in an ugly geometry (with a big hole). This would affect the stability of the clips, and the screw heads would press against the bearings, which could misalign them again.

Anyway, I will publish the tighter fitting version later today. The screw-reversal will be held back until I find something that works better.

comments.author: MartinMajewski

comments.text:
You can use the aluminium IGUS AWMP-08 rods if you use IGUS RJ4JP-01-08 bearings; but they will give even more wobbling as those rods have slightly different tolerance (thinner at most) - and even more wobbling if you use RJZM-01-08, has they have still different tolerances (larger at most than RJ4JP-01-08). I've AWMP-08 + RJZM-01-08on Y and AWMP-08 + RJ4JP-01-08 on X, and i'm not really satisfied by the Y. Also those rods bend more easily (may be an issue for very heavy prints), and you CAN'T use them with normal metal ball bearings.
If you want the maximum quality, i suggest using Misumi rods and bearings, they'll have no wobbling at all as they have an interference fit rather than a clearance fit (but they are noisier).

comments.text: Installed your bearing mounts. They are to loose on the bearing. I sanded them down a little to pull the bearing into the slot in the bottom of the bed plate but they really need a little removed from the part where they touch the bottom of the aluminum bed mount. Also the holes are way to big for the screws. They should be around 2.5mm for a m3x.5 screw. They look like they are closer to 2.8mm. This will let the threads strip out in the plastic. I would rather see the screws turned around the other way and use locking nuts on the aluminum side of the bed plate. This way you will not have to remove all the bed mount screws to install the bearing mounts. You could put small pockets in the plastic part for the cap head screws to fit into.

title: Wrist Gear for standard servo mount for Inmoov rotating wrist

description.text: I didn't like hacking up a servo mount (plus I didn't have one that would fit quite right) and then screwing it into the gear so I made this quick little hack using one of the pully mounts from the servo bed project and shaping it up and slapping the gear on top. This should fit on a standard servo and a screw can drive through the center into the servo cap. It might be a LITTLE tall so you can shave some of the bottom off. I'll probably make a cleaner version later.
Should be able to just print and use.

Glow sticking, LED POI manipulation, fire juggling and human pyrotechnic, have all been a great fun part of my life.

The only issue i had during all theses years was not finding powerful enough LED POI that could get that WOW reaction from the crowd just by turning them on.

This accomplishment could only be using fire POI or pyrotechnic materials. For that reason i have always been on the look for very power-full LED POI.

The search is over, thanks to 3D printing, i could finally design my own LED POI, or better, my SUPER BRIGHT BLINDING LED POI :) have a look at the video.

http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Powerful-LED-POI/?ALLSTEPS

The RGB STEEL 3D Printer is intended to be a nice looking, low cost, strong carbon steel frame, compact, color mixing, easy to assemble reprap 3D printer.

The machine is a redesign of the famous steel frame P3Steel 3D printer, with the advantage that now it can be equipped with a Diamond Hotend that allows for color mixing 3D printing, and lodge at least 5 bowden extruders for even more color mixing.

This instructables also servers on how to install a diamond hot end onto any reprep like machine using ramps 1.4 and Arduino Mega.

Have a look at the build process here:

http://www.instructables.com/id/RGB-STEEL-Low-Cost-Steel-Frame-Color-3D-Printer/

mini ITX/DTX case (from sheet metal - needs lasercutting and bending)
  • dual slot PCIe GPU (full height, half length 180mm long)
  • effective aircooling by 2x 120mm
  • no optical drive
  • no 3.5" drive
  • SFX PSU
  • as small as possible (some airgap for GPU/PSU though)
  • mini ITX or DTX motherboards

  • as many 2.5" drives as possible

  • modified Silverstone USB I/O and a 19mm dia pushbutton are expected for case finish (you can do without/run your own though, if you take the correct files)

  • final dimensions: 310H x 149W x 240D (w/o feet)

• Decide if you want any of the HDD mounting brackets, both are optional. Though I suggest for stability to take at least one if space permits.
    (An ASUS DCII GTX 760 Mini might be too wide for the hdd_gpu_mount option and a Thermaltake BigTyp Revo might be to high for the hdd_cpu_mount option)

  • Give the files to a lasercutting business and tell them how much of each part you want (you need 2 doors) and the metal sheeting they should be using (instead of alu you could use stainless for example).
    Tell them also that there are bend marks in the dxf files and that they should be appearing on the lasercut parts. Also they need to know metal sheet thicknesses (see pdf or list below).
    Beware that you are really on your own if you deviate from these:

    • 2mm: BaseFrame, USBio, HDDcpu, HDDgpu
    • 1.6mm: LoopShell, Door(s), PCIlock

  • Back from lasercutting the pieces need to be bended. The dxf files already contain bending marks, which should have been transfered onto the metal sheets during lasercutting - very faint lines where the bends are supposed to be on aluminium.
    Your shop of choice should be comfortable with the dimensions given for the bends and the maximum deviations for the desired final dimensions of the bended parts (accuracy! see pdf). The shop I used with the prototype needed several tries till they got the base frame right.

  • I have the open edges of the loop shell welded shut for my case.. this can be done by the metal sheet bending shop in most cases as well - though make sure the parts fit before they weld this (fit base frame into loop shell to test).

  • If all went well you now should have the final pieces and can start to think about surface finishes. Did I mention that all steps before need to be very careful not to scratch or dent the parts? Ok, now you know.
    Before surface treatment you should use some flat pliers to bend the cable tie mounting holes a bit inwards, so the cableties clear the doors later on.
    • ...from here on it's uncharted waters... The original plan was to use self adhesive velcro to hold the doors in place and although this worked well, the thickness of this solution didn't convince. This means you have to drill the missing mounting holes into the doors now, before they get surface treated.
    I will put up a version of the doors with 2mm dia pilot holes, but don't expect them to align perfectly with the base frame/loop shell as the bending can stuff up things. Use those on your own risk! I didn't decide yet for mine on surface treatment.. it's either anodizing or powder coating. Once that is done you can start to mount the Rivnuts/Nutserts. There are:
  • 4x M3 for the motherbaord used as standoffs
  • 8x M4 for holding the loop shell onto the base frame (and the doors as well)
  • 2x M4 for the PCIlock
  • depending on your choice of HDD mount 4x M3 per mount
    • Finally there is the assembly of the 19mm pushbutton with cables/connectors and the drilling of the Sivlerstone USB IO pcb (see pdf) to get it fixed to the USBio mount.
    If you want you can also mount some feet to the bottom of the loop shell - 30mm diameter feet fit well. ..some more info + pics from the prototype that I will add later on Thingiverse can be found on [H]ardforums in the Small Form Factor section here: JTS-air - open source mITX case for DIY

author: arral00

description.text:
http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Syringe-Pump-Rack/

This instructable serves to document the build process of a 3D Printed Syringe Pump Rack. The rack is composed by 5 Syringe Pumps, with this set-up you can have 2 continuous flow systems and one remaining pump (if you have the proper tubing's and valves).

A Syringe Pump is normally used to gradually administer small amounts of fluid to a patient or for use in chemical and biomedical research. Normally they allow for infuse and withdraw capabilities.

Here are the main features of this particular 3D printed Syringe Pump Rack:

  • Open hardware/software

  • Extremely compact size ( 7cm movement range )

  • High precision lead-screw and nut

  • Low cost (300€ for the 5 syringes)

  • Simple to use (command line interface)

  • Simple to replicate

  • Minimal clean Design

description.text:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Mega-Prusa-i3-Rework-8-x-Build-Volume/

The Prusa Titan concept was first introduced by the company named BluePrinted.com.au on October 8 2014, however to this day the company did not publish the blueprint's for the build of the large Prusa i3 3D printer.

Because i found the concept very interesting i took the liberty of sharing my version called Mega Prusa i3 Rework. The Mega Prusa i3 rework is basically an enlarged version of the Prusa i3 Rework. Is is scaled up from the original design. To be more precise, the Mega Prusa i3 Rewrk is scaled um in order to allow 8 times the build volume of the Prusa i3 Rework, a stunning 400x400x400mm.

description.text: This is an arduino project intended to allow control of your Makerbot without the need for a computer with ReplicatorG installed.  It uses an IR remote to simplify connections.

Firstly I need to thank codexmas without whose original work this would not have made it as far as it has. His original code is available on GitHub here: https://github.com/codexmas/makeIRbot My code continues to use the majority of his, however I have added some features from his last commit. This project gives most of the same controls over your Makerbot as ReplicatorG but without the need for a computer.
It will allow you to:
See Makerbot name and firmware versions.
See current temperatures.
Set target temperatures.
Jog X/Y/Z axis.
Run extruder forward and reverse at setable RPM.
Print a file from the SD card.
Enable/Disable the Fan.
Reset the Makerbot. You will need:
An Arduino. A run of the mill arduino 328 will do just fine with the current code.
A Hitachi 44780 LCD. codexmas' original code was based on a 16x2 display, mine is based on a 20x4.
A 38KHz IR receiver. I just used one that I had in my junk box, codexmas suggests used a TSOP39238CZ1
An IR remote control. I used an Apple Remote as it works well and doesn't have too many more buttons on it than are needed for this project. Some remotes will not work as they send their codes multiple times, the Sony remote I tried did this. The code uses additional libraries to do the heavy lifting for the menu, specifically MenuBackend and IRremote for the remote handling. I have attached the specific versions I used. To Build:
Wire up the display and the arduino as shown in the image and program the arduino.
The code was intended to be used with the Arduino-1.0 IDE and will almost certainly have issues with anything earlier. The additional libraries (I think) have been updated to work with 1.0 as well. Hook up the arduino's serial pins to pins 4 and 5 on the Makerbot's FTDI header. For testing I hooked up the arduino's Gnd to the Black (pin 1) on the FTDI header and +5V to the I2C header.
If you have wired everything correctly the first screen should tell you the name of your Makerbot and the firmware versions of the motherboard and extruder controller.
Then you will need to add your IR remote controls codes into the arduino sketch, press the buttons on your remote that you want to use and note the numbers that come up on the LCD. You will need to add these into the IR_Setup.ino file in the appropriate places and then reprogram the arduino again. I coded this to work with a Cupcake Makerbot with a 5D shield and version 3.1 firmware. However I think it may work on the Thing-o-matic as well. The jog function will likely have to be redone to work with anything older I suspect. Uploaded V1.9 - added settable jog distance.
Uploaded V1.91 - uploaded correct Serial_Commands.ino

comments.text: Nice.  I was working on the same idea and was about 50% along when I was distracted, and found this when I came back to work on it some more.
comments.author: Darkith

comments.text: Nice, glad to see you have tweaked things. Happy to merge changes if you want to contribute back to the github repo. One thing I wanted to add was IR code learning, so people don't have modify to code for their particular remotes.
comments.author: codexmas

comments.text: Thanks  :)  I had considered adding IR code learning in early, but I figured I should get the important bits working first.  Another thing I'm considering adding now that i have firmware version querying working is to change what commands are sent to the 'bot depending on what version of firmware it has.  I'm happy to merge it back into main line, I've posted the current code on Github as well so you should be able to see my fork.
comments.author: codexmas

description.text:
A broom hanger using a simple cam mechanism.  No bolts required.  
To give the cam grip I added some stick on foam.  
This one is printed in 0.25 layer height with 0.15 infill in PLA and it seems plenty strong enough.  
It is designed to be mounted with 6g 30mm screws.  
UPDATE:  Added base v2.stl.  This one has a stronger pin.

Note: When you load this into your printing software you will need to rotate 90 degrees on the X axis.  
Print it out, add some self adhesive foam to the cam so it grips.  Alternatively you could print the cam in a Arnitel or maybe Ninja Flex so it grips.  
Attach the cam to the base and mount it to the wall.  Make sure the cam moves freely on the shaft.  The cam should fall down when there is no broom in it.  
Then stand back and marvel how good your 3D printer is!  :-)

comments.text: Tried using stick on foam weather stripping first but the weight of the brooms just pulled it off over time. I used hot glue in a thick layer afterwards. It works much better.

author: comPVter

title: Flash Drive Cryptex - Combination Lock for your data

description.text:
Make your USB stick physically safe by printing a combination lock for it. The NSA won't stand a chance! This is still a work-in-progress. It does work, but there are still some things that need improvement. I would be happy to hear your ideas and thoughts. Please also take a look at the customizable rings for version 1
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193892 and at the improved, long-awaited version 2
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1196989 Again, I would be happy if you'd leave a comment.

Here are the parts you'll have to print:
  • USBCaseA.stl
  • USBCaseB.stl
  • Cover.stl
  • Jacket.stl
  • Spacer.stl (3x)
  • RingX (4x consisting of your desired combination)
    • For the case you'll have to disassemble your flashdrive and fit the circuit into the two halfs of. I printed them with support material. Depending on your drive you might have to carve it into place a little bit, because I designed it for the drive I had laying around. Now glue the two halfes and the drive together. For ABS this shouldn't be a problem. If your using PLA (like me) I recommend you using some slow-hardening epoxy glue. Worked just fine for me. Stick your printed number rings on the jacket. They must be separated by the three spacer parts, otherwise the cryptex won't lock. In the end you'l have to glue the Cover to the jacket, so the rings can not come off. Now you should be ready to go. Enjoy! !!!New customizable rings!!! There is a new OpenSCAD script I wrote. Now you're able to customize your rings. With this you can:
  • Choose the unlocking position for your rings
  • Change the symbols (Letters, numbers special signs)
    • Just download the zip-file, open the CustomizableRingRev1.scad, type in your parameters, press F6 to compile and finally go to "Design > Export as STL..."

comments.text: May I know  can DTSE9 G2 USB3.0 fit in ?

comments.text: How hard would it be to add a second flash drive to the other end?  Same rings but 2 combination, one for each drive?
comments.author: diablodel3

comments.text:
I think this would be problemtic.First of all you would have to inflate the whole model to fit two flashdrives (The cases should remain printable). On the other hand you could only use a combination to unlock both at the same time, if you are using the same tooth length for both drives. If you tried to unlock one, but not the other, the first drive would be blockes.
You could however use different teeth lengths to achieve this, but again you would have to make the whole thing bigger.
I don't quiete see the advantage. Do you have a special purpose in mind?

I have tested all five objects on my Replicator 2 using the standard make option in MakerWare Version 2.2.2.89.

title: IBM Model M Typewriter Keycaps for German edition

description.text:
Typewriter-style IBM Model M keycaps. Also perfect for a steampunk keyboard conversion. Features the keys for the German (European?) edition of the Model M with big enter key.

I used these files as a basis: https://github.com/jaseg/Model-M

Most files are untested! I only printed the standard keycap and it worked on my Model M. I never tested the other STLs though.

Print upside down for vewer support structures.

Description of files:
keycap.stl is the standard keycap of the IBM Model M.
space.stl is the spacebar.
big_enter.stl is the enter key.
big_shift.stl is the right shift key.
backspace.stl is the backspace and Num 0 key.
num_enter.slt is the Num Enter and Num + key.

comments.text:
What printer did you use to produce this at a workable level? I did a quick print (admittedly can slow things down, reduce layer size, etc. to get it better), but it wouldn't fit my Model M or Model F keyboard.
Secondly, what software did you use to open and then modify the original .scad files (if not OpenSCAD). I'm looking at the daunting task of modifying the original .scad file and can't open it in freecad, or sketchup, and while it may very well prove profitable for me to learn openscad in the end, it is not something I'm wanting to do just to change the basic design of the top of the model.
That being said - THANKS FOR THIS!! I've been trying to learn freecad TO MODEL the keys for my own project, and having something like this already designed puts me lightyears ahead of that steep problem. I still need to learn, but editting a model is easier than learning to create in freecad.
comments.author: takieda

comments.text:
Sorry, I complete overlooked your comment! So, even if a year late, I'll respond ;-)
I have a Zortrax M200, and as you experienced yourself, it is sadly not good enough to print the caps :-( They do fit my Model M fine, but they are not detailed enough for flawless typing (meaning, the keys hang much to often which is very annoying). Perhaps sanding the hook-thing after printing would make them better.
On your second question, I dont remember, but I somehow converted them to STL .. and I used Blender3D to do all the editing. Perhaps Blender could also convert the files ...

Asymmetric carabiner with internal hook.  Inspired by the mas design titanium carabiners.  
Printed with MadeSolid green PET+.  70mm with a 17mm gate.  
Of course these are non-load bearing.  If you need something strong, Trango, Metolius, Mammut, and quite a few other companies make some very nice aluminum carabiners.

The design uses gaps of 0.2mm which may fuse together with some printers/filaments.  It's designed to work with MadeSolid PET+.  ABS and PLA aren't flexible / elastic enough for the hinge (it will work, but the hinge will be fragile)

description.text: it is my first try on 3D Modelling world
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5M4LVCYsHBn

This is my own take on the illustrious first shotglass.. and the ultimate proof-test for your reprap!
It's quite a challenge to print as you will have to pause it several times during the narrow bit, or it won't harden in time. That said.. it's completely waterproof, contains about 25cc and it's oh so stylish! Do not forget to toast to your trusty reprap with your favourite spirit.

PLA highly recommended due to non-toxicity, do not print this in ABS if you intend to use it! Make sure you don't set the inner perimeter too fast, i've printed it with these settings:
Perimeters: 3
Solid layers: 3
Fill density: 1.0
Speeds:
Perimeters: 30mm/s
Small perim.: 10mm/s (your mileage may vary)
Infill: 40mm/s
Solid Infill:60mm/s
200 degrees The rest is standard. Make sure you pause the printer when the small part starts to wobble, fan recommended! Alternatively, as suggested in the comments, you can use the "cool" option in Skeinforge.

description.text:
A Raspberry Pi case shaped like a Nintendo 64. This is a remix of Foolish_Daves model, enhanced to really work as a raspberry case!

Works perfectly with every version of Raspberry Pi B+/2/3, but still no proper closing mechanism. Glue or screw it together.

The window in the top is for some plexiglass and an IR-sensor. I also added an alternative top without the window. You can print whichever you like better.

The reset and power button of the N64 are carved out now, but I did not test if they could work as buttons already. The idea is to mount a dip switch beneath and connect it to the reset-pins of the Raspberry Pi.

description.text:
fidget spinner toy shaped like the batman's logo.
78mm diameter, 7mm high.

two versions:

  • three 608 ball bearings (22mm)
  • one 608 ball bearing (22mm) and two holes for coins (each hole will fit three 5 cents brazillian Real coins, which are fortunately 22mm in diameter)

three caps:

  • low profile, 23mm in diameter, covering the bearings completely
  • high profile, 19mm in diameter, which will fit standard playstation/xbox rubber joystick caps
  • simple cap for the coin's holes

recomended settings:
0.2mm layers
50-75% infill
no supports needed
4-lines thick walls

WARNING:
The holes for the bearings are 22.5mm in diameter. If you want a tight fit for the bearings, downsize the model to about 98% in your slicer.

Please, share it if you print it!

title: Prusa i3 mini X-carriage for GT2 belts with 30mm spacing

description.text:
I really like the parts published with Prusa i3 Improved for Laser Cut variant by twelvepro (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39889), and especially the design of Y-belt Clamp and X-carriage. The teeth grip on the belt very tight - much better than on original parts.
However I found out that mounting holes on X-carriage are 24mm apart but the new standard for Prusa i3 parts is 30mm (for example on Greg's Wade extruder for Prusa i3 by misan). So I modified the part to enlarge the spacing to 30mm but keep the overall shape.

title: Anti wobble pad _ for CTC prusa i3 pro B

description.text:
Make sure the surface is perfectly smooth.
Print two with symmetry.
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5e862e0a8ac9fea29ccbd342/w/82a0aadeeaab73c47d75f338/e/a3667c4e8de71c010144504e

comments.text: Where is the left side one? You need the holes to be opposite for the opposite side!
comments.author: 3Dthat

comments.text: just twist it clockwise without flipping. should work in both sides
comments.author: 3Dthat

comments.text:
I spent a lot of time trying to eliminate Z-wobble on my CTC printer, including various printed couplings and anti-wobble pads similar to this design.
What really helped is replacing the crappy threaded rods with proper T8 lead screws. They don't have to be name-brand and expansive, I got my pair for $15-20 from eBay. I'm using them with the original flexible couplings and modified top mounts that leave them unrestricted and Z-wobble is gone completely. See the photos here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1383913
comments.author: gtcdma

comments.text:
Hola lipki,Falta subir el lado del motor, que yop me imprimi 2 pensando que valia y nanai...
Hi lipki, you have missed to upload the motor side part, I had printed the one 2 times thinking they are the same, but no.
after testing it they dosent work at all... the extruder motor hits the antiwooble before the stopper is reached, I cant understand it, looking the pictures i was sure that our printers were the same.
comments.author: karl_azytzeen

comments.text:
In some cases, yes, it reduces the physical links between the Z and X axes.
It's up to you, as MKSA says, it's a gadget, a well-tuned printer does not need to.
Me, I like it, it allows to make free movements on the axis Z, for maintenance.
comments.author: lipki

comments.text: thank you. il give it a try
comments.author: lipki

comments.text: does this make any difference?
comments.author: rattus911

comments.text: Yeah, an other anti wobble gadget that partially hides but doesn't solve the problem ! Do you realize that your screw, motor coupling, incorrect assembly ... are really screwed up and lead to this "wobble" ?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Yes i realize that.
The threaded rods are loose, my couple are not flexible, and my frame is not rigid.
comments.author: MKSA

title: K40 laser cutter interlock cover and block

description.text: I added a cover interlock to my Chinese made K40 laser cutter. I have the style that has a cover prop built in. I used a RadioShack SPDT Switch with roller lever for the interlock switch and mounted it to the side of the cutter with double sided tape. author: Seb200

title: FPV ground station mount for tripod

description.text:
This is my mount for a cheap FPV ground station using a generic 7" LCD screen from ebay + my video receiver 5.8 ghz RC832 + a DVR. Then you can just connect everything to any tripod.

The reason for this upgrade was to replace the original metallic mount accessory that comes with the screen. Once you start to add weight it becomes unstable and eventually cracks.

To add the nut for the tripod I used a generic gopro tripod mount (super cheap on ebay) as a donor for the nut. Then drilled with a 10 mm bit a hole and then using hot air (480 degrees Celsius) I placed the nut against the plastic (the nut is just 1.5 mm bigger than the hole) and heated the nut while pushing it down gently with a screwdriver.

title: Vertex K8400 optimized belt tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my optimized belt tensioner for the Vertex K8400.
My belt on X-Axis was very loose, so I have created a new tensioner.

With this one you need an open belt (I just cut mine).
To reach a good tension I cut off some teeth (1-4 - be carefull! just cut one by one!).

The print quality was significantly increased!
The top part was made to easily grab and realign the assembled parts.
